strIntroduction: When it comes to winter traditions in Okinawa, sugarcane harvesting is as traditional as it gets. There are few harvesting experiences available for tourists, but this tour will allow you to stay at a farmhouse and help harvest sugarcane for one week. You'll also receive some gifts for the time that you worked. In addition, you can do some sightseeing in Okinawa! Schedule: Day 1: The farmer will meet you the first day at the Naha Airport arrival lobby and drive you back to the farmhouse. If there is time, you may be able to do some sightseeing on the way to the farmhouse. Day 2 & 3: You will go to the sugarcane field to help farmers with harvest work from morning to the evening, about 8 hours in total each day. Day 4: You have a free day to do some sightseeing in the area. A taxi guide will take you to popular sightseeing spots in Okinawa by taxi all day. You will visit the popular Churaumi Aquarium and see the superb views of traditional houses in Kui Ohashi and Bise village. Day 5 & 6: We'll harvest sugarcane all day. Supper on the 6th day will be a farewell feast. Let’s dance some local dances and live it up! Day 7: The farmer who has taken care of you will drop you off to Naha Airport. *The pick-up and drop-off service is also available at your local hotel. *This experience is ideal for those 16 years and older, with confidence in their physical strength and full of volunteer spirit!
strTitle: Harvest Sugarcane during Okinawa Homestay

strIntroduction: In this tour, you will eat at Miyawaki, a small Japanese restaurant located in Yotsuya Sanchome, which is only a five minute train ride away from Shinjuku. Each dish will be served with a filling of Sake that matches the dish. I, as the host, will provide you with detailed explanations of each dish and sake, using a brochure which you are welcome to take home and show off to all of your friends. A typical Japanese cuisine consists of: Sakizuke (Appetizer) Owan (Soup) Otsukuri (Sashimi) Yakimono (Grill) Nimono (Stew) Agemono (Fry) Sunomono (Marinade) Shokuji (Rice) If you happen to prefer wine, we will prepare the perfect bottle of wine to match with your dinner for an additional fee of up to 5000 yen. Food preferences (allergies, etc) should be notified at least three days in advance please. Any extra food or drinks you order will be charged at the restaurant. If you have any questions, or need detailed instructions on how to get to the station, please don’t hesitate to ask! I’ll be glad to help! :) If you are interested, we can also do a Tsukiji tour in the morning, and go buy some fine fish that the chef can cook your meal with. Please contact me for details on the optional tour to the Tsukiji tour market!
strTitle: Savour Japanese Cuisine paired with Fine Sake

strIntroduction: This activity offers not only a tea ceremony, but we also let you wear a Kimono,and a professional hairdresser will make your hairstyle as you like. Our Hotel is close to Nagoya Castle. The tea room in Nagoya Castle is not open everyday. Schedule: Morning: 10:30 - enter the beauty salon 12:00 - preparation finished 12:30 - go to the tea room 13:30 - return back the kimono at the hotel Afternoon: 12:00 - enter the beauty salon 13:30 - preparation finished 14:00 - go to the tea room 18:00 - return back the kimono at the hotel
strTitle: Let's join a tea ceremony dressed in Kimono (May 15th)

strIntroduction: Yukata is a traditional summer wear in Japan and many foreigners love it. Except in the summer, it's very difficult for tourists to find shops selling Yukata, but we can bring you to of the nicest shops which sell inexpensive Yukata. We will visit that shop, try on any Yukata you like, and the host will give you an advice if you need. The host has a rich experience of Yukata shopping with foreigners. The shop is close to Shinjyuku Gyoen National Park. Available days: Monday - Friday Time: 11:00 am - 19:00 pm
strTitle: Yukata shopping experience in Tokyo

strIntroduction: In Japan it is common to have your own chopsticks, rice bowls, or tea cups at home. Let's make your own chopsticks which totally fit your hands. We will learn Japanese table manners and play a game with your handmade chopsticks. 1. Cut materials made of Japanese cypress which smells very nice 2. File and put organic bee wax including aroma oil made of orange and ginger. 3. Learn Japanese table manners 4. Practice using chopsticks properly and play a fun game After the class please take the chopsticks you made back to your home and use them! **Kids can also enjoy making chopstics, besides the wood cutting part. Available days: Date: Monday - Friday Time: 10:00-12:30, 13:00-15:30, 16:00-18:30 **We can be flexible. If you want to join this activity on other days, please feel free to contact us.
strTitle: Make your own chopsticks and learn manners through games

strIntroduction: Start the tour just before sunset to take advantage of the best light conditions. Meet the photographer at Shimbashi station and get acquainted with the necessary photography techniques for this tour. Away from the usual touristy tracks, shoot the first half of the tour in Shimbashi. The area known to be the office worker’s haven. Hordes of “salary-men” wearing white surgical masks flock to the entertainment district after work. It’s a common scene of modern day-to-day Tokyo. You will use interesting characters and the graphic environment to your advantage. You will learn how to create interesting and artistic images out of the mundane. Take a short train ride to the next station and change scenery completely. Neon lights and lanterns light the path under elevated train tracks. Capture life in the untidy and colorful eateries and other entertainment districts. Step into modernity again and take photos of people within geometrical shapes at the Tokyo International Forum. Finally, the tour concludes on an observation deck in front of newly renovated Tokyo Station. You will not need a tripod for this tour. If you’d prefer more long exposure photography check out our “Tokyo by Night” tour. Technicalities: For this day and night photography tour / workshop we have seen great results with smart phones. However, we highly recommend that you bring a camera with manual overrides (M, Tv, Av, A or S modes) and a versatile zoom lens such as 18-105mm. Rough itinerary: Meet the group at JR Shimbashi station 10 minutes for technical preparation 1 hour and 20 minutes shooting in Shimbashi 1 hour shooting in Ginza The tour concludes in front of Tokyo JR station [Average walking distance: 2 kilometers (1.3 miles) with ups and downs steps in train stations] This tour is held on all Fridays, and on Tuesdays between March 15 and May 31, as well as between September 1 and November 30.
strTitle: Tokyo Photo Tour - Tokyo Metropolis

strIntroduction: Enjoy a night out with us in one of the coolest and most vibrant cities in the world. Going from bar to bar in the bar crawl style, led by professional but also crazy guides who will be sure to show you a night you'll never forget. Shinjuku Ni-chome is the LGBT area of Tokyo. It is a mixture of trendy, gritty, and awesome. It is a different side of Tokyo and makes an interesting alternative from the Tokyo night scene. Explore 3 bars and a club whilst receiving free welcome drinks and meeting new friends, all in one fabulous night out in Tokyo's gay district that is sure to not disappoint! COME PARTY WHERE THE LOCALS PARTY! Who is it for? At the Tokyo 'Pink' Bar Crawl we welcome all people of all shapes and sizes from all walks of life, whether they be gay, straight, curious, bi-curious, looking to party, non alcoholic drinkers, cat lovers, dog lovers, anime geeks, foodies, walking enthusiasts, foreigners, locals, expats, young, old, employed, unemployed.......our doors are open to anyone! How it works: We have an organized bar crawl once a month. It will be a bar crawl with other groups in addition to yours. If you would like to join a bar crawl on a night we are not hosting an event, then we may be able to organize a private one just for you! (this is dependent on the number of people and availability of the organizer). We will pick you up at Shinjuku Sanchome station, exit C7. We will head over to the first bar and wait for everyone to gather. A free welcome shot will be given to our guests. After an hour or so of drinking and socializing with our new friends we will move on to explore the other bars on our tour, where you will receive a welcome shot on entrance. Each bar has its own theme and will allow you to really experience how the locals party. We will end the night at one of the main clubs in Ni-chome. Our bar crawl will end around 23:00 after taking you to the club. People looking to get the last train back can come with us to the station or for the party animals wanting to stay till the early morning hours, the first train from Shinjuku station can be caught at 5:30am. The upcoming organized group bar crawls are: Friday, May 22, 2015 Other events will be advertised closer to the time.
strTitle: Tokyo's Gay Bar Crawl

strIntroduction: Your otaku expert guidewill walk with you for two hours through the amazing Akihabara neighborhood. The maximum group size is ten people which allows an intimate conversation among guide and participants about the fascinating, lovable, weird, and obsessive aspects of otaku culture. Otaku culture—the private world of Japan’s boys and men who live in a fantastic virtual world of manga and anime—has become a phenomenon with international appeal. One of the centers of otaku culture is the neighborhood of Akihabara on the eastern side of Tokyo. Enjoy a fun and insightful introduction to the atmosphere and products and lifestyle of Akihabara in just a couple of hours, with lots of tips for choosing the best places to experience further at your own pace. Please dress casually. There is a medium amount of walking, including some stairs. Most of the activities are indoors, so this tour is not canceled for weather except in extreme situations. Public WiFi is not available along most of the route of this tour. Please respect privacy of individuals and of merchants by refraining from closeup photography of individuals and store merchandise without asking permission. This tour is offered regularly on Saturday afternoons on a non-private basis and also on a private basis subject to the guide's availability and times that neighborhood stores and attractions are open.
strTitle: Introduction to Otaku Culture (Akihabara)

strIntroduction: We will gather at 11:30am in central Tokyo and travel together by train to Kita-Kamakura, a major center of Zen Buddhism in Japan. We will enter a major Zen temple founded in 13th century, and join a Zazen, an open Zen meditation session for Japanese laypeople led by one of the temple's monks. We will sit cross-legged on meditation cushions on the floor, but it is not at all required that we sit in true full- or half-lotus position; in fact, many of the Japanese participants will not be doing so. In any case, please wear clothes comfortable for sitting. Your guide will brief you in advance on temple protocol and what to expect during the Zazen, which will consist of two separate 15- to 20-minute sittings with a break in between and brief comments by the monk (in Japanese). After the Zazen ends we will explore the elegant grounds of the temple and other temples close by. Photographers and nature lovers will be enthralled by the beautiful settings. We will also visit a few shops offering local crafts and other gifts. We will then go to a nearby one-star Michelin restaurant famous throughout Japan for its Zen vegetarian Shojin Ryori cuisine. There we will enjoy a multi-course meal as well as explanations of the Shojin Ryori tradition and what we will be eating. By 7:00pm we will be back to Tokyo, satisfied and perhaps a bit more serene than when we started.
strTitle: Zen Experience in Kamakura

strIntroduction: Hi! I'm Dariush, I have been living in Japan for 4 years. I would like to show you the real side of Kichijoji that can only be fully experienced when living here. Get a chance to visit Kichijoji's most famous parks, shops, temples and much more. KIchijoji is one of the most popular areas for people to spend their weekends. It features one of Tokyo's most varied and complete shopping areas, as well as the beautiful Inokashira Park and zoo. It is no wonder that Kichijoji has been voted the No. 1 place where people in Japan would like to live since 2004. Following a pick-up at Kichijoji Train station, we will take you on a stroll to the beautiful Inokashira park where you can admire the lake, the shrine, the stunning colors of the Japanese trees (cherry blossoms can be seen all around the park during spring) and enjoy the entertainment from musicians and street performers that gather at the park. You can enjoy another perspective of the park by riding on the lake with one of the many swan boats that are available for hire. After the stroll you will have surely worked up an appetite and where better to go than one of Tokyo's most famous yakitori restaurants. Iseya is famous for its skewered chicken and many varieties of skewered food (skewers start from 80yen onwards). Iseya has been serving food since 1958 and has recently been refurbished to give it a unique Japanese look. Another option is to visit Harmonica Yokocho, once a post war flea market. Now a small cluster of alleyways that are filled with small bar and restaurants. This is a unique and vibrant experience with the bustle of diners crowding the trendy standing-only bars and miniature eateries. Kichijoji has an array of shops and small boutiques. Once finished with your food, we will take you to browse some of the unique shops Kichijoji has to offer. The tours ends back at Kichijoji station and you are free to continue shopping or exploring this great town at your own leisure.
strTitle: Discover Kichijoji - Tokyo's favorite town

strIntroduction: First, I will pick you up at Hattori Tenjin station or Esaka station. Then we will drive to my house and dress up in a kimono. After we're all dressed, let's go to the game center to take purikura. When we're done, we will go back to my house and undress, and I will drop off at the station. Purikura, a Japanese sticker photo, is not known very much around the world but It has been very popular among young generations in Japan for over 20 years. Not only does it come in the form of stickers, but you can also download them on your phone or other electronic device. Take it home as a souvenir of Japan! I had been learning traditional Japanese dance for 18 years. I acquired a teaching license (called Natori) and used to teach traditional Japanese dance classes, until I got married. I love Japanese traditional culture so I would love to share it with people who are interested in it as well!!
strTitle: Wear a Kimono and Take a Sticker Photo in Osaka

strIntroduction: We will meet at Akasaka station, and the dance room (Studion Faith Akasaka) that we will have our class is a 5-minute walk. Once we arrive to the dance room, please choose your favorite Yukata, a traditional Japanese wear. You can choose an Obi belt that goes with your Yukata as well. After changing into Yukata and get hair arrangement, the host will explain to you the basic information about Yukata, summer festivals, and Bon Festival dance. Then we will start practicing the very basic dance moves. We will then teach you other dance moves and you will soon be a Bon Festival dance master! If it is sunny and we have time, we walk to local shrine and take pictures. I look forward to your participation in my class! **This class is for 4 people or more.** *Some photos are from dance summer festival but this class is a dancing in a room class* <Availability> -Weekdays. -Time Slots: 10:00am-12:00pm / 1:00pm-3:00pm / -We can be flexible with our schedule, so please feel free to contact us if you need other dates and times
strTitle: Experience Bon Festival Dance and Wearing a Yukata in Tokyo

strIntroduction: 11:00 Meet up at Odaiba station Visit TOLOT/heuristic SHINONOME This hotspot for contemporary art that opened just last year. Due to its somewhat unusual setting inside an old-fashioned multi-unit steel building, you can also see factories and warehouses for a spectacle that you might not normally encounter. Next we will visit Miraikan, the National Museum of Emerging Science and Innovation. With exhibits and frequent events that allow visitors to experience cutting-edge scientific technology, there is something new to enjoy every time. It’s also extremely popular among foreign visitors, and is regularly selected by overseas media as one of Japan’s must-visit attractions. Stroll through the delicious IROHA HONTEN A good stroll works up an appetite! With “Monja Street” lined on both sides with nearly 75 monjayaki restaurants you will be able to find your perfect monjayaki joint. 15:00 Return to Tsukishima Join this tour and make your day unforgettable!
strTitle: Explore Tokyo Bay Area With Art and Local Cuisine

strIntroduction: Materials used for the Temaki Sushi- Sushi-rice(vinegard rice) row fishes and vegetables nori (seaweed sheets) usuyaki tamago ( thin omelet) white radish sprouts Depending on what you would like to cook .we will have different ingredients ready for you! Please tell us in advance of what kind of food party you would like to experience!
strTitle: Visit a Home in Osaka and Enjoy a Food Party,Oct 12th

strIntroduction: **Update** This tour's host is currently unavailable. However the following experience is similar and currently available: https://www.govoyagin.com/activities/japan-tokyo-private-tsukiji-tuna-auction-watching-tour/528 Experience the energy and excitement of Tokyo's premier Tuna Auction at the infamous Tsukiji Fish Market with a professional and knowledgable tour guide! The guide Kiyoshi will guide you every step of the way to watch the Tuna Auction and teach you about the history of Tsukiji and the food industry in Japan from his many years of experience working in Japan's Hotel and Food & Beverage industry. Be one of the first people to arrive at the Tuna Auction site at 3am to reserve your spot and see first hand as the early morning brokers check deep inside the famous tuna using flashlights as they assess the quality before the Tuna Auction. Then witness the infamous Tuna Auction between 5:30am and 6:00am. Participants will be able to experience this exciting daily event live and see the extravagant prices paid for high-quality tuna. After watching the Tuna Auction, you will complete your morning with sushi for breakfast at a highly-recommended restaurant. The sushi will surely be the freshest fish you have ever eaten! (Please note: Breakfast is not included in the price of the tour.) ※ Time Schedule: 3:00am Meet the Tour Guide at Tsukiji Market 3:30am Register for the Tuna Auction 5:00am Move to the Tuna Auction Market 5:30am Start of the Tuna Auction 6:00am Finish of the Tuna Auction 6:30am Breakfast (end of the Tuna Auction Tour)
strTitle: Private Tokyo Tsukiji Tuna Auction Tour in English

strIntroduction: You can easily become a 'Japanese Gyaru', a prevailing fashion for teens and early twenties in 2000s by changing your hair and clothes! Apply heavy-make up and wear stylish clothes to turn into a Japanese Gyaru for a day! We will help you with the transformation by styling your hair, applying make-up, and by providing you with interesting facts and information about the Gyaru culture. You can choose how long you want to be a Japanese Gyaru within one day. You can also take a photo after you have transformed into a Japanese Gyaru! Photo Credits: https://flic.kr/p/RqaDh https://flic.kr/p/5LV7Hj https://flic.kr/p/bvayg3 https://flic.kr/p/276DJy
strTitle: Transform Into a Japanese Gyaru in Tokyo!

strIntroduction: Do you have a favorite anime character that you would like to transform into? If so, we will help you out with the transformation! We will take you to the hair dresser and will cut your hair, apply hair extensions, make up, and dye your hair so that you will look exactly like your favorite anime character! After your transformation, you can hit the streets and hang out in Shibuya, Akihabara, Harajuku, or anywhere you want to! If you wish to bring your own costume, please feel free to do so! If you do not have any costume, you can borrow them from us! Why not take this opportunity to transform into an anime character while you're in Japan!? Take amazing pictures of yourself as an anime character!
strTitle: Transform into an Anime Character in Tokyo

strIntroduction: Experience the Japanese tea ceremony and meditation in the suburb of Tokyo, Atami! We invite you to a tea ceremony at a traditional house, which is located in an area with great Japanese architecture! We will be serving Japanese tea and sweets, as we talk more about Japan! You will also be able to experience Zen meditation under the guidance of a master! The tea ceremony and the tour of the traditional guesthouse will take one hour. The meditation will take about 30 minutes. The guesthouse was built in the 1920s and was used as a villa that was owned by a famous Japanese CEO. When the Emperor of Meiji period was thinking about relocating the capital from Kyoto to Tokyo, he decided to have a villa in Atami even though there were many other popular places. A lot of nobles had villas in Atami in those days and there are still a lot of villas that belong to famous companies. -Access- Atami is located 50 minutes away from Tokyo by train, and it is also within the Japan Rail pass area. You can enjoy the hot springs with both the mountain and ocean scenery. Narita International airport - Tokyo station : 60 minutes by train Haneda International airport – Tokyo station : 30 minutes by train Tokyo station – Atami station : 50 minutes by bullet train : 2 hours by train (Tokaido line) Nagoya station - Atami station : 2 hours by bullet train Kyoto station – Atami station : 2 hours by bullet train (change to Tokaido line at Mishima station) We can pick you up at Atami station. It will take about 10 min to get to the guesthouse. We look forward to meeting you!
strTitle: Experience Meditation & the Japanese Tea Ceremony in Atami

strIntroduction: Okinawa is known for the beautiful beaches, unique foods, and the hot summer weather. When you visit Okinawa, you will be spending most of your time at the beach, enjoying activities like snorkeling, diving, para-sailing, and etc. If you are at the beach, why not do a BBQ party with your friends or family on the beach? It would be the perfect opportunity to stay on the beautiful beach while being full with delicious BBQ food! As your guide, I will introduce you to Okinawa's pretty beach and serve you savory BBQ food and Okinawa Orion Beer! This will also be a great opportunity for you to mingle with the locals and to learn more about the culture of Okinawa! Most Okinawan people go to the beach to hold BBQ parties on the weekends or during their summer breaks! We promise you to hold great, fun BBQ party! We look forward to seeing you!
strTitle: Enjoy a BBQ Party by the Beach in Okinawa!

strIntroduction: Best of Nagoya 1 Day Private Tour Experience the history of Japan, learn the world's top class technology of auto-industry, mingle with the locals for lunch and shop till you drop with a national licensed tour guide!!! Itinerary ******************************************************** 9:00 Meet with our English speaking guide at hotel in Nagoya ①Nagoya Castle & Palace (90min). ②Tokugawa Gardens & Museum(60min). Lunch ③TOYOTA Commemorative Museum of Industry and Technology 90min ④Osu Kannon Temple & Shopping Arcade 120min 17:00 Back to hotel
strTitle: 1 Day Private Tour in Nagoya

strIntroduction: Ever wondered how the local people enjoy their summer evening in Japan? Most people purchase handheld fireworks and enjoy spending a nice evening with their friends and family! Japanese people also love to eat somen (thin, cold noodles) in the hot, summer weather! Handheld fireworks, somen, wearing the yukata, are all things you can only experience in the Japan, during the summer! In this experience, you will be experiencing the local Japanese summer life! Here is the schedule of the tour! 17 : 00 Meet up at Tenjinbashisuji 6-chome station (2 stations from Umeda Station) Go to a supermarket and buy some ingredients for dinner (Somen) 18 : 00 Somen Dinner (Japanese summer noodle) You can learn how to cook somen (it's so simple!) If the weather is good, we can enjoy dinner on the rooftop of my flat. 20 : 00 Handheld firework on Yodo River (10 minutes walking from my place) 21 : 30 Finish I live in a share house, so some of my friends may join us. The more people, the more fun! Come join me in this summer event, and learn more about Japan! I look forward to meeting you!
strTitle: Spend the Summer Evening Enjoying Handheld Fireworks!

strIntroduction: The small town of Uji is famous for its tea, which is considered to be the best in Japan. However, 1000 years ago, this pretty area was surrounded by gentle rolling hills and a quiet rushing river. Some 20 km from Kyoto is a road to Nara, where princes and nobles chose to build their country villas. Come visit Uji to see and feel the old Japanese scenery, with shrines, temples, and traditional houses! Itinerary: We meet at Keihan-uji station (8:30) ↓ ① Ujigami-shrine(9:15) Ujigami Shrine (“shrine” is called “jinnjya” in Japanese) is a Shinto shrine in the city of Uji. In 1994, it was registered as a UNESCO World Heritage site. It is about a 20 minutes walk from Keihan-uji station, and is located in a residential street. (NOTE: UJI-gami shrine is under construction until the end of this year (2014). You will be able to enter, but you won’t be able to see some areas) ↓ We move to the next destination through Wasarabi Street, which is a stone-paved road. You can enjoy a quiet walk through a lovely, rural area. ↓ ② Zen at Kosho-horinji Temple (10:30) In this activity, you will be able to experience Zen practices at koshoji. This temple held the first meditation-in-Zen-Buddhism exercise hall for the Dogen Zenji . You can learn about Koshoji from a Japanese movie called [ZEN]. You can place yourself in the sacred air of Dogen Zenji. (NOTE: Each event stops during the Year's End and New Year holidays (12/30～1/3) and the following periods.( 5/16, 8/12～14, 9/26～29, 10/first Sunday,12/1～4) Please confirm beforehand. ↓ ③ Lunch time(12:30) ↓ ④ Make your own dishes at Asahiyaki Pottery.(13:30) Asahiyaki Pottery has been in Uji for over 400 years. Nestling between rice fields and near to the scenic Uji River, it is possible for you to experience making your own teacup or bowl. Beginners at pottery do not need to worry, as a full explanation will be given. After firing your finished work, it will be sent to you (within 1-2 months). At the pottery museum, the works of successive generations of potters are on show! You will be able to choose from the following 2 courses. 1.Electric potter wheel experience . This is a trial lesson using the electric potter's wheel. (The finish is entrusted to you by the staff.) 2.Picture charge account experience. You will be able to draw a picture on the pottery which the staff has produced , including plates, a teacups, or bowls. ↓ We go through Jusanjunotou at Ukishima. The tower was elected for fishery prohibition and is a dedication of a new bridge over Uji River. It is said that ancient fishing implements were buried under the tower. ↓ ⑤Byodo - in Temple(15:30) Byodo-in temple has been also registered as a UNESCO World Heritage site. It was constructed by Fujiwara no Yorimichi, in 1052 during the glory period of the Fujiwara family. Phoenix Hall (Ho-o-do), an Amida Buddha hall, was built in the following year, and is a National Treasure. As you may know, Ho-o-do hall is displayed on the Japanese 10 yen coin. The Hall has undergone construction and was completed this April, making the hall even more beautiful! ↓ We move to the next destination through Byodo-in omote sando Street. There are many old kinds of tea shops here. You can smell tea just walking there. There are many types of tea-production, and Japanese typical goods, so you can buy souvenirs here! ↓ ⑥Making green-tea and taking a break(16:30) We will go to Mitsuboshien-Kanbayashisannyu-Honten, which is a long-established store that started in the Tensho Era. Along with the long history and tradition that it has inherited, the store is known as the home place of the master of the tea ceremony for the Shogunate. There, you will be able to experience the making of powdered green tea (Maccha). The staff will provide you with detailed and simple instructions so that first-timers can enjoy preparing tea on their own. After that, you can go to Uji Tea Reference Library in the same building. ↓ ⑦Watch Japanese traditional fishing , ”Ukai” , from a boat.(17:30,18:00) Cormorant fishing (Ukai) is a traditional fishing method in Japan and China.(“cormorant” is called “u” in Japanese) To control the birds, the fishermen tie a snare near the base of the bird's throat. This prevents the birds from swallowing larger fish, which are held in their throat, but the birds can swallow smaller fish. When a cormorant has caught a fish in its throat, the fisherman brings the bird back to the boat and has the bird spit the fish up. This looks a little cruel for the cormorants, but you will be impressed how strong the ties are between the fishermen and the cormorants! (NOTE;You can watch this tour from another boat, but this service is only available during 6/15～9/21). The starting time changes depending on the season. 【6/15～8/31】 Tour reception 18:00 Boarding 18:30 Outgoing vessel 19:00 The end of Ukai fishing about 20:00 【9/1～9/21】 Tour reception 17:30 Boarding 18:00 Outgoing vessel 18:30 The end of Ukai fishing about 19:30 At the time of stormy weather and rising waters due to the Amagase Dam discharge ,the Ukai fishing tour may be cancelled. Please confirm tour availability beforehand. Come visit Uji and experience the Japanese culture through different aspects! From tea making, watching the cormorants, and making your own pottery!
strTitle: Explore the Traditional City,1 Day Tour around Uji in Kyoto

strIntroduction: If you're wondering where to go with your family in Kyoto, we have plenty of ideas for you! We offer tailor made tours for your family! These tailored family trips will provide you with a wonderful, exciting time during your stay in Kyoto! Here, we list some of the " must visit sightseeing places " in Kyoto. Just choose where you want to visit with your family! Our tours duration is mainly 5 to 7 hours. It depends on your itinerary. ****************************************** some more details are below our web-page http://kyoto-sake-brewery.com/ ****************************************** We only accept one family a day, since each tour is a private tour just for your family! Please note that the price does not include the lunch fee. **** My Must Visit List ********** 1. Kiyomizu Temple (include Ninenzaka and Sannenzaka streets) -An independent Buddhist temple located in eastern Kyoto. It was founded in the early Heian periods. There is not a single nail used in this entire structure! 2. Sanjusangendo temple 3, Fushimi inari shrine -Is a Shinto shrine located in Southern Kyoto. It is famous for its thousands of vermilion torii gates. The gates will lead you to Mount Inari, which is known to be a sacred place. 5, Golden pavilion 6, Ryoanji temple -Is known as Japan's most famous rock garden. 7, Ninnaji temple 8, Arashiyama (Bamboo forest, a monkey park and Togetsu bridge) -A place filled with temples, shrines, and a bamboo grove. 9, Silver pavilion 10, Path of philosophy (approximately 2.3 Km) 8, Gion (Hanami ko-ji street and pontocho) -Kyoto's famous geisha district 11, Nishiki food market and Teramachi & Shinkyogoku shopping arcade 12, Nijo castle -A flatland castle located in Kyoto. This castle was completed in 1626. **** Places you may want to visit****** 13, Uzumasa studio park * 2,000 yen/person extra cost 14, Kyoto imperial palace 15, Toji temple 16, Tofukuji temple 17, Heian shrine 18, Kyoto city zoo 19, Kitano tenmangu shrine 20, Manga museum 21, Nara from Kyoto * 2,000 yen/person extra cost 22, Kobe from Kyoto * 2,000 yen/person extra cost 23, Osaka from Kyoto * 1,500 yen/person extra cost **** Model plan 1***** 1, Golden pavilion 2, Ryoanji temple 3, Ninnaji temple 4, Arashiyama (Bamboo forest and Monkey park) 5, Coming back to Kyoto station **** Model plan 2***** 1, Fushimi inari shrine 2, Sanjusangendo temple 3, Kiyomizu temple 4, Gion 5, Nishiki food market 6, Coming back to Kyoto station **** Model plan 3***** 1, Sanjusangendo temple 2, Kiyomizu temple 3, Silver pavilion 4, Path of philosophy (2.3 km) 5, Nishiki food market 6, Coming back to Kyoto station *********************** If you're visiting Kyoto with your family, let us help you out to make your stay in Kyoto unforgettable! ****************************************** some more details are below our web-page http://kyoto-sake-brewery.com/ ******************************************

strIntroduction: Have you ever wanted to belt out some tunes at the karaoke? If your answer is " I don't know" I guarantee there is a chance that you don't know what you are missing! A trip to the karaoke box is one of the most uniquely super fun things to do in Japan. Everyone is a little shy at first, but that is why we always choose the ALL YOU CAN DRINK plan. Where people start loosening up, and decide to sing their favorite songs with no shame! You can put back as many drinks as you like during our stay but of course we encourage you to know your limits so that you can still get home safe. We will invite a couple of local friends along to help you see how it's done before we hand over the mic to you. Remember that in Japan it doesn't matter if you have a great voice or not to give karaoke a go. You can choose to pick a sing-a-long hit from the Beatles or the latest Beyonce solo. There are thousands of songs in English to choose from. After the music is over, we can go for an ice cream or to a local bar and share some of the fun photos from our fun night at karaoke.
strTitle: Experience a Karaoke Box Party in Kyoto!

strIntroduction: Do you know how to distinguish good sake from the variety of sake that is sold in the stores? In Japan, there are thousands of sake breweries and they sell more than a thousand different types of sake. Some sake are super good, but unfortunately some are not. Did you know that bad sake gives you bad hangovers but good sake does not? It's difficult to find good sake if you don't have any idea about sake! In this experience, I will take you to a local sake shop and give you some tips to find good sake.Then we have a party with the sake, along with some Japanese snacks at my house. I live with seven other people at a share house! You will enjoy dinner with my housemates and friends! Schedule : 18 : 00 Meet up at JR Temma station A small walking tour through Tenjinbashisuji- shopping street (the longest shopping street in Japan) Find a good sake at a local sake shop. 19 : 00 Dinner at my home with sake and locals 22 : 00 Finish Come join me and my friends for delicious dinner and amazing sake!
strTitle: Home Party with Friendly Locals and Great Sake in Osaka

strIntroduction: Kyoto is one of Japan's historical city, and has many tourists visiting every year to see the temples, shrines, Japanese gardens, old narrow streets, and the towns where you can see and feel the four seasons. Not only does Kyoto provide tourists with amazing scenery, it is also known for the delicious traditional food and drinks! There are many sake breweries in Kyoto, which you will be able to visit in this tour! In this tour, you will learn how to brew sake, whiskey, and beer. We want you to learn how to taste sake through all your five senses. You will be amazed by the different tastes that exist! Tour Itinerary: 1. Meet up at Karasuma chuo exit, entrance of Kyoto station at 8:50 a.m. ★ Inside of Kyoto station and it is on the Kyoto tower side 2.Take the JR line to go to Yamazaki distillery. ★ We will try 2 or 3 glasses of yamazaki whiskey 3. Eat lunch around Nagaokakyo station. ★ Eat typical Japanese lunch (not for vegetarians) 4. Go to the Suntory beer brewery. ★ Try 3 glasses of beer 5. Go to the Sake brewery in Fushimi district. ★ Try 3 types of sake 6. Take a look around Fushimi district. 7. Come back to Kyoto station. Come and enjoy the tastes of Japanese alcoholic beverages in Kyoto!
strTitle: Enjoy a 5 Star Sake Tasting Tour in Kyoto!

strIntroduction: "The tour will begin with a guided inspection of the sumos’ morning exercise routine led by an “oyakata”, a retired sumo wrestler who coaches the sumos. Becoming a coach requires a high ranking, tournament performance, and a great deal of financial support, so your guide will know everything there is to know about sumo. Following this visitors have an opportunity to take their photos with the sumo wrestlers. A sumo wrestler's meal is eaten together with young wrestlers. The meal, known as “Chanko-nabe”, is a filling broth rich in veggies and protein. The sumo eat this dish in vast quantities year round, and it’s a key part of their training. Get a taste of the dish that gives the sumos their power - and size! All visitors will receive a copy of the current banzuke as a gift. The banzuke is a traditional document that dates back to 1761 - and is a highly important part of the sport. Every current professional sumo can be found somewhere on this document, with a ranking based on their wrestling performance. The names are painstakingly written by hand in a traditional style. What better souvenir to take home from a visit to a sumo stable? The location is easily accessed by a 3 minute walk from the Toei Metro Hama-Cho station, or a 7 minute walk from the Tokyo Metro Ningyocho station. This tour is provided courtesy of the Arashio-Beya sumo wrestling team."
strTitle: Watch Sumo Morning Practice in Ningyo-Cho (near GINZA)

strIntroduction: Want to try a Samurai Armor on? At out dojo, you will be able to wear the traditional samurai armor. This short experience is intended for Japanese cosplayers who want to try a real armor on and have photos taken. International travellers can take thes course, but please know that this is not an introductory class to teach histories or philosophies. This experience will give you an insight into the Japanese culture. It takes about 15 minutes to have a traditional armor on. Photo taking time is approximately 15 minutes. Please read the following explanations before you come to our dojo. About yoroi (armor) The samurai armor is usually very colorful and sometimes very ornate. The warriors wanted to stand out in front of their lords. They wanted their lords to notice them in the battlefield. And when they die, they wanted to die gourgeously. Those who wore red armors were regarded most valiant. The samurai armor was always designed for mobility. A good suit of armor had to be sturdy, yet flexible enough to allow its wearer free movement in the battlefield. The armor was made of lacquered plates of either leather or metal, carefully bound together by laces of leather or silk. The arms were protected by large, rectangular shoulder shields and light, armored sleeves. The warrior's face and brow were protected by a piece of armor that tied around behind the head and under the helmet. The most famous feature of the helmet was its Darth Vader–like neck guard (Darth Vader’s design was actually influenced by samurai helmets). It defended the wearer from arrows and swords coming from all angles. Many helmets also featured ornaments and attachable pieces, including a mustachioed, demonic mask that both protected the face and frightened the enemy. About Weapons As soldiers, samurai employed a number of different weapons. They originally carried a straight blade called "chokuto." As sword-making techniques progressed, the samurai switched to curved swords, which eventually evolved into the katana. The katana is perhaps the most famous sword type in the world and certainly the most iconic of all samurai weapons. Bushido (the code of warriors) dictated that a samurai’s soul was in his katana, which made it the most important weapon he carried. Katanas were usually carried with a smaller blade in a pair called “daisho,” which was a status symbol used exclusively by the samurai class. In battles, the samurai warriors commonly used the yumi, a longbow they practiced religiously with. Then, spears. When gunpowder was introduced in the 16th century, the samurai abandoned their bows in favor of firearms and cannons. Their long-distance weapon of choice was the tanegashima, a flintlock rifle that became popular among Edo-era samurai and their footmen. Cannons and other gunpowder weapons were also commonly employed. In the period of "Warring States" in the latter half of the 16th century, personal bravery on the battlefield was replaced by meticulous planning and tactics. About Bushido -The code of warriors The life of the Samurai not only became one of discipline and military education, but a rich cultivation of the spirit and mind through the arts of writing, painting, calligraphy, philosophy, etc. Zen Buddhism and Confucianism provided the warrior class with personal enlightenment, and refinement. The unwritten Samurai code of conduct, known as Bushido, held that the true warrior must hold loyalty, courage, veracity, compassion, and honor as important, above all else. An appreciation and respect of life was also imperative, as it added balance to the warrior character of the Samurai. He was often very stoic with a deep and strong philosophical passion. He could be deadly in combat and yet so gentle and compassionate with children and the weak. This Stoicism was realized out of a genuine respect for life and also for death.
strTitle: Become a Samurai in Tokyo for a day!

strIntroduction: When traveling in Osaka, you can encounter tasty food that you can rarely eat at home or outside of Japan. I would like you to take home the taste of these traditional Japanese dishes by learning how to cook them. I would like to invite you to a shared flat to cook these dishes with the locals! Osaka is known for great local foods such as Okonomiyaki, which many people refer to as Japanese Pizza, where cabbage, seafood, meat, etc is mixed and served on a frying pan. Otherwise, Takoyaki, Doteyaki and Kushikatsu are famous traditional local foods that many enjoy. Takoyaki is another popular food shaped as a cylindrical ball, where a piece of octopus is placed inside. The Doteyaki has beef tendons served on skewers, where it is stewed in miso flavored sauce. The Kushikatsu, which are Japanese styled deep fried skewers can be enjoyed with various vegetables, seafood, or meat of your choice. By learning how to cook traditional Japanese dishes, you will be able to immerse yourself in the Japanese culture and be able to present your cooking skills to your friends and family back home! It is also a wonderful opportunity for you to get to know the Japanese culture by getting to the locals who live at the shared flat. These traditional Japanese dishes can be cooked by Vegans, Muslims, and anyone with a strict diet since the ingredients can be altered to suit your needs. We look forward to cook these amazing Japanese dishes with you! Photo by https://flic.kr/p/4GLwMz
strTitle: Cook and Taste Japanese HOME Dishes in Osaka

strIntroduction: Japanese people love drinking tea. Tea has been a part of our culture and lives for a very long time. These days, there are many abandoned tea fields in Japan. But there is one farmer who has been reviving the green tea field landscape and developing more organic tea farms. In this tour, we will visit an organic tea farm in Nara and experience picking and processing organic tea leaves. --Schedule-- 9:00 Pick up from Kintetsu Nara Station. ↓ Walk through the tea fields ↓ Tea leaves picking ↓ Lunch ↓ Tea processing ↓ Teatime ↓ Back to Nara station Learn how to care for organic tea fields and process green tea like a farmer! Availability : Please get in touch with me before you make a booking.
strTitle: Experience Tea Farm in Nara

strIntroduction: Are you satisfied with only visiting famous tourists sights? Wouldn't you like to experience some true Japanese culture while in Tokyo? Expect the sushi you make to be delicious because we will be providing the freshest raw fish for your lesson! If you are a vegetarian, we will prepare vegetable sushi. You can choose any ingredients to mix Okonomiyaki, so let us innovate a new Okonomiyaki. (Including foods and drink.) strIntroduction: The Shinto Kanamara Matsuri, "Festival of the Steel Phallus" is the festival most popular with visitors to Japan, and also the most outrageous! Come join the Voyagin team for this craziest of all Japanese festivals!! There will be themed illustrations, candy, carved vegetables, decorations, a mikoshi (portable shrine) parade, and of course a visit to the sacred shrine. The Kanamara Matsuri is centered around a local penis-venerating shrine once popular among prostitutes who wished to pray for protection from disease. It is said that there are also divine protections for business prosperity and for the clan's prosperity; and for easy delivery, marriage, and married-couple harmony. There is also a legend of a sharp-toothed demon (vagina dentata) that hid inside a young woman and castrated two young men on their wedding nights. As a result, the young woman sought help from a blacksmith, who fashioned an iron phallus to break the demon's teeth, which led to the enshrinement of the item. https://flic.kr/p/7QCKcB https://flic.kr/p/JBbZg https://flic.kr/p/7QCHQk https://flic.kr/p/7R2U8p http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/07/Kanamara-mikoshi2.jpg
strTitle: [April 5th] The Craziest Japanese Festival Kanamara Matsuri

strIntroduction: Sakate island is a small fisherman village, which has around 450 people. There are no traffic lights and few cars seen in its backstreets and alleyways, giving the aura of an old-fashion Japanese village. Once you walk up a path along the hill, you will be able to smell the fresh fragrance of grass and nature. Take a deep breath! The schedule for this activity is flexible. We can go fishing, walking, or just relax by the sea if you wish. You should also try the delicious chicken available on Sakate island. Anybody can try their hand at fishing, even if you're a beginner or a child. I will prepare the fishing equipment and fish feed. If you want to bring a fish back after fishing, please bring along your own cooler box. There is a kitchen nearby the fishing spot where you can cook and eat your fish as well! (Rental of the kitchen will cost a little extra) Let's enjoy fishing and walk the streets of Sakate Island!
strTitle: Go Fishing and Walk the Streets of Sakate Island
Explore Seaweed Forest on a Kayak Tour!

strIntroduction: In this tour, we will visit Toba harbour, known for its richly nutritious waters which gives rise to a conducive environment for sea creatures such as fish, shellfish, and seaweed. Seaweeds are seasonal, you can see different colored seaweeds in the water depending on the season. Experience hunting for seaweed with local fishermen! All the seaweed were bred with care by the local fishermen themselves. First, you will take a 3 minute boat ride with fishermen and a guide to reach the harvest point. Once you arrive, the local fishermen will give you a brief lesson on how to hunt seaweed. Next, you will try seaweed hunting by yourself! All you have to do is cut it with a knife. Anybody can enjoy hunting seaweed. You will also get to taste the seaweed that you bring back with you to the boat. Thes fresh smell of the sea and juicy texture is something you can only taste with the freshest of seaweeds. Finally, you can enjoy seaweed ''Shabu-Shabu'' and homemade rice balls which are made from seaweed from Toba harbour. Enjoy hunting and eating fresh seaweed and shabu-shabu!
strTitle: Hunt and Eat Fresh Seaweed and ''Shabu-Shabu''

strIntroduction: Have you heard about 'Setsubun'? Feb 3rd is called 'Setsubun' in Japan Setsubun literally means the "division between two seasons"-winter and spring. The Setsubun ceremony is held on February 3, where the Japanese celebrate with a bean throwing ceremony and eat Eho-maki (Fortune Sushi Roll). You can experience making and eating Eho-Maki at the cafe that are located very closed to Kaminari-mon which is the gate to Nakamise-street, a cafe in Asakusa near Kaminarimon. There are 3 traditional rules of eating Eho-maki: １．You must face the lucky direction of the year. ２．You should eat the entire Sushi Roll at one go. ３．You should not speak until you have finished the sushi. People believe that they will receive good luck if they can eat a whole sushi roll without making any noise facing the south-southeast direction, which is believed to be the lucky direction for the year. You can make your own original Eho-maki and enjoy it with soup! If you are in Tokyo on 2nd or 3rd of February, you should celebrate 'Setsubun'! Please come and join us! ※This service is for reservation only. You will need to pay an additional 1500JPY for 'Setsubun' fortune sushi roll lunch.
strTitle: 1 Day Event on Feb 3rd! Eat Special lunch in Asakusa

strIntroduction: Kichijoji is one of the most popular parts of Tokyo - CNN reported in 2011 that it was the number 1 neighborhood for Tokyoites to want to move to! There are many varied food and clothing shops in Kichijoji, as well as the beautiful Inokashira Park. I will introduce you to these interesting places in Kichijoji. Kichijoji is also well-known as the place where the ghibli museum is located. Example Program: 1) Gather at Kichijoji station and walk around the locality. You will find a huge variety of shops such as clothing, game arcades, snack shops, perfume and so on... 2) Move to Inokashira park. It takes about 10 minutes on foot from Kichijoji station. We'll walk around the inside of the park, and take some pictures if you like. 3) Return to Kichijoji station. If you want to eat something, I'll introduce you to a restaurant and we'll eat some delicious food together. If you are not hungry, I'll drop you off at the station and we'll say goodbye! If you want to experience local atmosphere, you should join this tour!
strTitle: Discover Kichijoji - one of Tokyo's Favourite Neighborhoods
Let's Go Cycling to Late Night Lake Biwa & Ramen Supper

strIntroduction: In this experience you will be making yatsuhashi from scratch and also visit the factory where Nama yatsuhashi (raw, unbaked yatsuhashi) is being produced. In this Japanese town house you can also relive the atmosphere of old Kyoto. Yatsuhashi is a Japanese confectionery sold mainly as a souvenir sweet. It is one of the best known meibutsu (famous regional products) of Kyoto. It is made from glutinous rice flour, sugar and cinnamon. Baked, it is similar to senbei. Raw, unbaked yatsuhashi (Nama yatsuhashi) has a soft, mochi-like texture and is often eaten wrapped around red bean paste, and may come in a variety of different flavours. Photo URLs http://flic.kr/p/654yi8 http://flic.kr/p/5GCcWo http://flic.kr/p/9WqjuU http://flic.kr/p/FfXvF
strTitle: Learn to Make Kyoto's Most Famous Souvenir: Yatsuhashi
